_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Ammonia Compressors, Condensers, Accumulator, Pumps, Ventilation Systems and Purging Systems and Emergency shut down system
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Land O'Lakes Tulare, Ca. facility contains 1 Program Level 3 refrigeration system process that uses Anhydrous Ammonia. The process at the facility is the Plant 1 & 2 main refrigeration system. The maximum amount of anhydrous ammonia in the Plant 1 & 2 system process is 33,776 pounds.  The Plant 1 & 2 ammonia refrigeration system is the only process present above the EPA threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds, and is designated as a Program Level 3 process and is subject to the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals Standard (29 CFR 1910.119). The reportable quantity for anhydrous ammonia is any release over 100 pounds in a 24 hour period. There have been no reportable accidental releases of anydrous ammonia at the facility in the last five years that have resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on site or off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



There are Two types of cooling systems utilized in the Land O' Lakes Tulare Plant 1 & 2 Main refrigeration system: absorption and vapor compression. In the absorption (or flooded) type system, liquid ammonia flowing from the receiver through coils of a heat exchanger, where either water or glycol are flowing counter currently on the shell side of the coils, is cooled by the liquid to vapor phase change of anhydrous ammonia as it boils. The anhydrous ammonia vapors are then compressed and liquefied in a condenser for reuse. The Plant 1 Ice Builder refrigeration system is an example of this type of system it is a latent heat storage unit which stores refrigeration in the form of ice. The latent heat storage resulting from the change in state from water to ice is the key to the success of these units. Large quantities of refrigeration can be stored in a relatively small space.

 

The ice is produced during periods of low demand for refrigeration or electrical energy. It is then used at a later time in the form of 32o F to 34o F cooling water. A vapor compression system consists of four basic components; the compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator. The cycle involves two pressures, high and low, which enables the system to produce a continuous cooling effect. Low pressure vapor is compressed, raising temperatures and pressure levels. During compression, heat of compression is added to the vapor as the pressure is raised. At the condenser, the high pressure vapor is liquefied by cooling. The liquid ammonia flows from the condenser to an expansion valve where its pressure and temperature are reduced. The ammonia moves to the evaporator where it absorbs heat from a fluid being cooled. Vaporized ammonia then flows to the compressor suction to complete the refrigeration cycle. The anhydrous ammonia vapors from both types of cooling systems flow through a liquid accumulator where any entrained liquids are knocked out of the gas stream prior to being compressed. This prevents damage to the compressors. The accumulated liquids are pumped back to the high pressure receiver.



The Land O' Lakes Tulare, Ca. Plant 1 & 2 Main refrigeration system is a closed loop system and designed to

run continuously. When required, the refrigeration system is recharged with anhydrous ammonia by off-loaded bulk anhydrous ammonia tanker truck to the ammonia high pressure receiver. Ammonia is off-loaded through the tanker's flexible hose connected to the high pressure receiver's hard piped charge line. Recharging only occurs when there has been a loss of ammonia from the system. Under normal operation, these losses result from fugitive sources (i.e., pump seals, valves,flanges) and from routine maintenance of equipment.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Land O' Lakes Tulare, California. facilities Risk Management Plan (RMP) is in accordance with and promulgated pursuant to Section 112(r) of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments. The plan conforms to the Draft Guidance Document for the California Consolidated Contingency Plan published by the Governor's Office of Emergency Services and is modeled after the National Reponse Team's Integrated Plan, the "One Plan." The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) has delegated implementation authority for this federal program to the California Office of Emergency Services (OES). At the local level, the program is implemented by the Certified Unified Permitting Agency (CUPA). For facilities operating within the City of Tulare, the CUPA is the Tulare County Environmental Health Department.



The Land O' Lakes Tulare, Ca. facilities consist of a creamery, engaged in the production of dairy products such as powered milk and butter from raw milk. Five (5) separate dairy processing facilities presently exist.

                           

Anhydrous ammonia, a regulated chemical is present above the EPA's threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds at the Land O' Lakes Tulare, Ca. facility. The plant 1 & 2 main refrigeration system is designated as a Program Level 3 process and subject to the requirements of the OSHA Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemiclas Standard (29 CFR 1910.119). The plant 1 & 2 main refrigeration system has a combined anhydrous ammonia inventory of 33,921 pounds.  



The federal threshold quantity for anhydrous ammonia is 10,000 pounds and the state threshold quantity is 500 pounds. The reportable quantity for anhydrous ammonia is 100 pounds. 



The Land O' Lakes Tulare, Ca. facilities RMP has been developed from a comprehensive assessment of all the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration processes, operations, and procedures at the facility and includes the following elements:



A Management System that specifies qualified and responsible persons;

A H

azard Assessment that analyzes and documents (1) the hazards of the process, (2) mitigating controls, (3) the consequences of failure of these controls, and (4) the potential environmental and population receptors due to an accidental release;

A Prevention Program that contains specific hazard and safety information, operational procedures, preventive and corrective maintenance procedures, a comprehensive personnel training program that minimizes the threat of an accidental release;

 

A Emergency Response Program that establishes procedures to deal with the results of an accidental release.



Land O' Lakes corporate and the management team at the Land O' Lakes Tulare, Ca. facility are highly committed to the prevention of incidents and accidents that may result in injury and/or illness to it's employees and the community, and to complying with all applicable Federal and State safety and health rules. Employees have the right to know about potential workplace hazards, and a right to participate in securing and maintaining a safe and healthy environment.



There have been no reportable accidental releases of anydrous ammonia at the facility in the last five years that have resulted in death, injury, or significant property damage on site or off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



The Land O' Lakes Tulare, Ca. facilities accidental release prevention and emergency response procedures to a Hazardous Substance Release are in accordance with and promulgated pursuant to the California State Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response Regulations (CCR Title 8, Section 5192), OSHA's Emergency Action Plan Regulations (29 CFR 1910.38a), OSHA's Process Safety Standard (29 CFR 1910.119), OSHA's HAZWOPER Regulation (29 CFR 1910.120) and the EPA's Oil Pollution Prevention Regulation (40 CFR part 112.7(d)).



Land O' Lakes Tulare, Ca. facilities general accidental release prevention program and chemical-speci

fic prevention steps;



Pre-Emergency Planning;



The Land O' Lakes Tulare, Ca. facility has determined to use a combination of internal and external spill responders.  [Tulare Fire Dept.] will assist in a spill response scenario.  Other agencies, such as, Police, Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC), and hospitals have been notified of our plan.



The local Fire Department will visit the facility at least annually to be familiar with the following:



Facility layout:



Names, amounts and locations of hazardous materials stored at this facility.

Locations of hydrants and other water sources.

Location of normal and alternate access roads, gates, fences, etc.

Surrounding building occupancies and land use.

Precautions and tactics for responding to chemical spills and/or fires.

Day and night telephone numbers of the facility operators, physicians familiar with the products, and manufacturers of the products.

Means of controlling drainage at and adjacent to the facility.

Symptoms of overexposure to hazardous substances.

Procedures to follow in case of contact with hazardous substances.

Situations requiring Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) and proper PPE selection.

Means of ventilating the building(s).

Methods of measuring levels of airborne contaminants.



Personnel Roles;



Spill Responders;



Spill responders at the Land O' Lakes Tulare, Ca. facility are trained to respond to releases or potential releases of hazardous substances by stopping a release, keeping it from spreading, and preventing exposures. Spill responders who will be assisting with the stopping and containment of a release are trained to the Hazardous Materials Technician Level (24-hour) and will attend annual 8-hour refresher training.  Spill responders will also receive an annual medical examination and respirator fit test, as specified in the Written Respirator Protection Program.

 

Local External Responding Team;



The local Fire Department will provide additional resp

ical exam, respiratory questionnaire, pulmonary function, and blood work.  The physician may request additional tests/information.



Personal Protective Equipment;

 

Personal Protective Equipment is provided up to Level A protection to be used in Immediately Dangerous to Life or Health (IDLH) situations.  The equipment will be maintained/tested according to the manufacturers guidelines.



Monitoring;



Upon initial entry, air monitoring equipment (gas meters or sampling tubes) will be use to determine chemical levels.  Monitors are calibrated on a semi-annual basis.



Periodic monitoring will be conducted to ensure conditions have not deteriorated since initial monitoring.



Situations that may require additional monitoring are as follows:



When work begins on a different portion of the site.

When contaminants other than those previously identified are being handled.

When a different type of operation is initiated.

When employees are handling leaking drums or containers or working in areas with obvious liquid contamination.



Emergency Spill Response Equipment;



Emergency Spill Response Equipment is purchased and maintained by the Tulare Land O' Lakes facility. The local Fire Department is responsible for the purchase and maintenance of its own equipment.



Emergency Response Plan Updates;



The Emergency Response Plan will be tested, reviewed and amended as necessary on an annual basis.



The plan will also be reviewed and amended if one or more of the following occurs.



The plan fails to be effective during an emergency.

The team updates general procedures.  This may result from a post emergency meeting.

Emergency phone numbers or contacts change.

There are changes in the amount, type, or location of emergency response equipment.

Plan revisions are identified during drills.

Applicable regulations are revised.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety; 



1. Management systems: Ensure that management practices and worker training give priority

to accidental release prevention.



2. Personnel training: Continue to provide the facilities anhydrous ammonia refrigeration maintenance technicians and operator personnel additional task based knowledge and hands-on-training to further enhance their technical skills and knowledge. 



3. Security measures: Improve facilities security by installing building and cold storage area security systems to minimize the potential for unauthorized activities.



4. Process design: Install additional sensors to allow better monitoring of the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration process conditions. Replace older reciprocating compressors with new more efficient screw compressors.
